newsitem.title: USA: RTRS-US VIEW-BHP Copper boss plans to slash costs.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-US VIEW-BHP Copper boss plans to slash costs.

text.p: BHP Copper boss Burgess Winter expects to slash up to ten U.S. cents a pound off production costs at its troubled Magma operations before the middle of next year and anticipates a rapid rise in the global price of copper in the next six months.
Winter, BHP Copper's Executive General Manager, told Reuters the price of copper "should be" around US$1.15 per pound rather than its current range of around 88-89 cents.
He predicted it would rise to well over the US$1.00 level in the next six months en-route to settling around $1.10-1.15.

Magma, the second largest copper producer in the world, was purchased by Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd (BHP) earlier this year for US$2.4 billion. It lost money for BHP, one of the largest listed companies in Australia, in the 1996/97 first quarter (June/August) -- a result which shocked the local share market and sent BHP's share price tumbling.
BHP has been badly bruised by the slump in copper prices, stimulated in part by the Sumitomo trading scandal which emerged mid-year and slashed copper prices by more than 25 per cent.

Shareholder anxiety about Magma's value to BHP was exacerbated when the BHP annual meeting heard last month that production costs at Arizona-based Magma had jumped to 85 U.S. cents a pound, compared with 68 cents when the takeover was completed in January.
Winter described the 68 cent figure as "misleading" but admitted 85 cents was "a little high".
"I'm looking at taking ten cents a pound off, certainly by the middle of next year," he said in a telephone interview from BHP's North American headquarters in San Francisco.

He said production problems, including a design flaw which is being overcome at one of the company's new Nevada mines and temporarily inflated charges for smelting and refining Magma copper, had contributed to the cost problem.
Winter maintained Magma's integration with BHP had gone smoothly and the company was poised to reap the benefit when the market "inevitably" turned around.
BHP has other major copper operations at the Escondida mine in Chile and Ok Tedi in Papua New Guinea.
Winter suggested further expansion in Chile and North America was likely and testing on a huge Argentine orebody was progressing well.

"It is the metal of the next century, the fundamentals of copper are just so strong it has to be enormously successful," he said, noting "producers don't have any inventory these days and ... consumers can't get any copper."
"I think we could see a significant increase in the copper price in the next six months - when I say significant I mean (to) well over a (U.S.) dollar a pound."
He predicted the effects of the Sumitomo trading scandal would be through the market in the next few months.
"If you look at history, the prices of copper right now, I believe should be of the order of $1.15 a pound.
"The reason it's not, is not clear but part of it may be the Sumitomo debacle."
Winter said "the market is absolutely crazy" but he predicted a bright time for the copper business in the medium term.
"Business is going great guns," he said.
